study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of His-Purkinje system pacing (HPSP) versus traditional cardiac resynchronisation therapy (CRT) in patients with pacing-induced cardiomyopathy (PICM).
results_summary: The study did not report specific results regarding Walking, as it focused on cardiac pacing therapies (HPSP vs. CRT) and their impact on cardiac function and patient outcomes.
population_specificity: 46 patients with PICM requiring pacemaker upgrade treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the early clinical effects of the femoral neck system (FNS) versus three cannulated screws for treating unstable femoral neck fractures.
results_summary: The FNS group showed lower postoperative pain (VAS scores), faster recovery to walking without crutches, higher Harris scores, and lower complication rates compared to the cannulated screw group, though with higher intraoperative blood loss and hospitalization costs.
population_specificity: 60 patients (30 pairs) with Pauwels type-3 femoral neck fractures (12 males, 18 females; average age ~54 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of sensorimotor training on spatiotemporal gait parameters in middle-aged and older adults with diabetic peripheral neuropathy (DPN).
results_summary: Sensorimotor training improved spatiotemporal gait parameters after eight weeks in both middle-aged and older DPN patients, with no significant age-related differences in outcomes.
population_specificity: Middle-aged and older adults with diabetic peripheral neuropathy (16 middle-aged, 21 older adults).
effective_dosage: Three days per week for eight weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of intramedullary nailing (IMN) versus conservative treatments (traction and casting, spica casting) for femoral shaft fractures in children aged 2-10 years, with a focus on rehabilitation outcomes like walking.
results_summary: IMN resulted in significantly less angulation, lower rates of leg length discrepancy (LLD), and shorter recovery times for walking with aids, independent ambulation, and full weight bearing compared to conservative treatments.
population_specificity: Children aged 2-10 years with closed femoral shaft fractures, with a subgroup analysis of children aged 2-6 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate walking, balance, and upper limb function in people with cervical dystonia (CD) and assess their relationship with CD severity and usual exercise.
results_summary: The study found that walking and balance in people with mild to moderate CD were similar to healthy populations, suggesting no significant impairment in these areas. However, fear of falling and gross upper limb function were worse in CD patients compared to healthy adults.
population_specificity: 22 people with mild to moderate isolated, focal, idiopathic cervical dystonia.

study_goal: The study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of resistance training (RT) for muscle strength, lean body mass, cardiopulmonary function, metabolism, quality of life, and pain in burned children.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that resistance training significantly increased muscle strength and lean body mass but showed no significant effect on muscle endurance.
population_specificity: Burned children

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical outcomes and mechanical characteristics of different internal fixation techniques (off-axis screw, dynamic hip screws, and parallel screws) for vertical femoral neck fractures in nongeriatric patients under walking conditions.
results_summary: The off-axis screw technique showed lower fixation failure rates and better interfragmentary stability compared to dynamic hip screws and parallel screws, with no significant difference in avascular necrosis among the groups. Biomechanical analysis confirmed the off-axis screw's superior stability during walking.
population_specificity: Nongeriatric patients with vertical femoral neck fractures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the neural circuit involved in action-stopping, previously studied in simple laboratory tasks, applies to real-world scenarios like walking and driving.
results_summary: The study suggests that the prefrontal-basal ganglia action-stopping circuit, identified in basic stop signal tasks, may also be involved in real-world activities like walking, though confirming this requires further research with improved methodologies.
population_specificity: Not specified (general neuroscience research, likely cross-species).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the fidelity of delivery of a nurse-led non-pharmacological intervention for knee pain, which included walking aids and other components.
results_summary: The study found that a trained nurse could deliver most components of the intervention with high fidelity, though fidelity was lower for advice on footwear and walking aids. The nurse reported challenges in advising on certain aspects, such as thermal treatments and goal negotiation.
population_specificity: Adults over 40 with chronic knee pain, meeting specific pain criteria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of lower limb resistance exercise on muscle strength, physical fitness, and energy metabolism in pre-frail elderly in China.
results_summary: The study found that lower limb resistance exercise significantly improved quadriceps femoris muscle strength, 6-min walking test performance, 30-s sit-to-stand test, daily activity energy expenditure, and metabolic equivalent in pre-frail elderly, with notable differences between the exercise and control groups.
population_specificity: Pre-frail elderly individuals in China (aged 65.3 ± 13.4 in the exercise group and 67.6 ± 11.9 in the control group).
effective_dosage: 12-week lower limb resistance exercise program (specific frequency and intensity not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effectiveness of music-based therapy (MBT) as a complementary treatment for improving motor and non-motor functions in individuals with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The study found that MBT was more effective than conventional therapy or no intervention in improving gait parameters, fatigue, coordination, balance, emotional status, and pain. Conflicting data were reported for mental fatigability and memory.
population_specificity: Individuals diagnosed with multiple sclerosis (MS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and effectiveness of prolonged-release fampridine (PR-FAM) in improving walking ability in adults with multiple sclerosis (MS) in real-world settings.
results_summary: The study found that PR-FAM improved walking ability and reduced the physical and psychological impact of MS, with 61% of patients showing improvement in walking ability after 12 months. Safety data indicated no new concerns, though some adverse events and seizures were reported.
population_specificity: Adults with multiple sclerosis, including those aged ≥65 years and those with pre-existing cardiovascular risk factors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify pre-operative prognostic factors (both mutable and immutable) associated with post-operative walking capacity in adults with lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS).
results_summary: The study found moderate-quality evidence that greater pre-operative walking capacity is positively associated with post-operative walking capacity, while spondylolisthesis and severity of stenosis were not associated. Most other factors had low or very low evidence levels.
population_specificity: Adults receiving surgery for lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding walking (using the XCO® device) to proprioceptive training with the Flexibar® could further reduce symptoms of lateral epicondylitis compared to proprioceptive training alone.
results_summary: The study found that both groups (proprioceptive training alone and combined with walking) showed significant improvements in pain, quality of life, grip strength, and vibration sensation, with no significant difference between the two interventions. Walking did not provide additional benefits beyond the proprioceptive training alone.
population_specificity: 71 patients with painful lateral epicondylitis lasting more than 3 months.
effective_dosage: At least 40 minutes of running or walking per week with the XCO® device.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of home-based walking on cancer-related fatigue in breast cancer patients undergoing anticancer treatment.
results_summary: Home-based walking significantly reduced cancer-related fatigue in breast cancer patients, with greater effects observed when walking was the sole exercise, duration was gradually increased, and intensity was unrestricted. Only three of the eight studies reported adverse events.
population_specificity: Adult patients with breast cancer receiving anticancer treatment.
effective_dosage: Not specified (gradually increased duration and no restrictions on intensity were noted).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a telerehabilitation program (TERECO) involving walking and other exercises was superior to no rehabilitation for improving exercise capacity, lower limb muscle strength, pulmonary function, health-related quality of life, and dyspnoea in COVID-19 survivors.
results_summary: The TERECO program significantly improved 6-minute walking distance, lower limb muscle strength, and physical health-related quality of life compared to no rehabilitation, with effects sustained at follow-up. No significant differences were found in lung function except for post-treatment maximum voluntary ventilation.
population_specificity: 120 formerly hospitalized COVID-19 survivors with remaining dyspnoea complaints from Jiangsu and Hubei provinces, China.
effective_dosage: Unsupervised home-based 6-week exercise program comprising breathing control, thoracic expansion, aerobic exercise, and lower limb muscle strength exercises, delivered via smartphone.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to critically review the measurement properties of mHealth technologies for monitoring functional skills in stroke survivors and identify adoption barriers in research and clinical practice.
results_summary: The study included 64 out of 1380 studies, with a majority focusing on lower limb behavior. It synthesized recommendations for clinicians on selecting mHealth technologies based on validity, reliability, usability, and privacy considerations.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the effects of real-time feedback on dynamic functional leg alignment and lower limb loading during walking on sloped surfaces, comparing ramp and treadmill walking.
results_summary: The study will provide data on frontal knee range of motion, ground reaction force loading rate, and other biomechanical parameters during incline and decline walking, with and without real-time feedback, to inform intervention planning.
population_specificity: Thirty healthy participants aged 18-35 years.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (intervention involves walking conditions, not a dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an advocacy training program in empowering seniors to advocate for more walkable neighborhoods and assess its impact on physical activity.
results_summary: The advocacy program increased seniors' advocacy confidence and skills, leading to environmental improvements like sidewalk repairs. While accelerometer-measured physical activity did not significantly increase, self-reported transportation activity rose in the physical activity comparison group.
population_specificity: Low-income seniors from four senior housing sites in San Diego, CA.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (behavioral intervention, not a supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical outcomes of idursulfase-treated and untreated Filipino patients with Mucopolysaccharidosis type II (MPS II), including effects on walking ability via the six-minute walking test (6MWT).
results_summary: The study found improvements in joint mobility and other clinical endpoints in the treated cohort, including positive effects on respiratory involvement and mortality rate, though walking-specific outcomes were not detailed.
population_specificity: Filipino male patients with MPS II (40 total, 8 treated with ERT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 450-ml blood donation would impair the performance of elite soldiers in laboratory and field environments.
results_summary: The study found no significant impact of blood donation on the participants' performance in either hospital or combat-like settings, supporting the feasibility of buddy transfusions in austere environments.
population_specificity: Elite soldiers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if nerve ultrasound (UPSS) could effectively monitor functional status changes, including walking ability, in patients with chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy.
results_summary: The study found that changes in UPSS were not correlated with changes in the 10-m walking test, indicating no significant association between nerve ultrasound scores and walking performance. However, UPSS changes did correlate with other functional measures like handgrip strength and disability scales.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (n=16).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the feasibility and effectiveness of interactive stepping exercise (ISE) on executive function and gait variability among community-dwelling older adults.
results_summary: The study found high retention and attendance rates for ISE, with significant improvements in Trail Making Test part A and stride length variability during cognitive dual-task walking after 12 weeks of intervention.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults (n=14, split into experimental and control groups).
effective_dosage: Three times a week for 12 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of augmented visual feedback during overground gait training on temporal gait asymmetry (TGA) in people with chronic stroke.
results_summary: The study found that high-frequency visual feedback (100% trials) using Display B improved TGA without reducing gait speed, while other feedback frequencies and displays showed mixed or no effects on TGA or speed.
population_specificity: Eighteen people with chronic stroke.
effective_dosage: 25 repetitions of 30-second trials with assigned feedback (acquisition), followed by 10 repetitions of 30-second trials without feedback 24 hours later (retention).
study_duration: Single session for acquisition, with retention testing 24 hours later.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate changes in disability, particularly walking ability, in patients aged 60+ undergoing multi-level spinal deformity surgery using the Oswestry Disability Index (ODI).
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in walking ability, with the largest improvements observed in pain, walking, standing, and other daily activities. At 2 years, 45.5% of patients showed ≥20% improvement in ODI, and severe disability (ODI >40%) decreased from 59.0% pre-operatively to 20.2%.
population_specificity: Patients aged ≥60 years undergoing primary spinal fusion surgery of ≥5 levels for coronal, sagittal, or combined deformity.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (surgical intervention, not a supplement).
study_duration: Follow-up at 10 weeks, 12 months, and 24 months post-operatively.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if physical activity monitoring with motivational feedback before, during, and after cardiac rehabilitation could meaningfully improve physical fitness in heart failure patients with reduced ejection fraction.
results_summary: The study will assess changes in the 6-minute walking test distance, step count, grip strength, quality of life, and hospitalization/mortality rates, but results are pending as it is a planned randomized controlled trial.
population_specificity: 180 heart failure patients with reduced ejection fraction (NYHA Class II/III) referred to 12-week cardiac rehabilitation.
effective_dosage: Not specified (personalized step goals via Fitbit Charge 3).
study_duration: Approximately 7 months (4-5 weeks pre-CR, 12 weeks during CR, 12 weeks post-CR).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-flow nasal oxygen (HFNO) delivered by a portable device during walking was more effective than usual portable oxygen in improving exercise capacity in patients with COPD and severe exercise limitation.
results_summary: HFNO significantly improved walking distance compared to usual oxygen supplementation (61.1 ± 37.8 m vs. 39.7 ± 43.8 m, p = 0.01), with no significant differences in dyspnea, oxygen saturation, or inspiratory capacity, but greater comfort was reported with HFNO.
population_specificity: 20 stable COPD patients with severe exercise limitation requiring an oxygen inspiratory fraction (FiO2) <0.60 during exercise.
study_duration: Single 6-minute walking test per condition (HFNO and control)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of brisk walking versus Sudarshan Kriya Yoga (SKY) on menopausal symptoms, quality of life, and hormonal changes in menopausal women.
results_summary: Brisk walking showed no significant improvement in hormonal levels (follicle-stimulating hormone and dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate) but was associated with no adverse events. It was less effective than SKY in elevating antioxidant enzymes (superoxide dismutase and glutathione peroxidase).
population_specificity: Menopausal women aged 40-50 years.
effective_dosage: Not specified (brisk walking intervention details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of a home exercise program delivered via telerehabilitation for youth with arthrogryposis multiplex congenita (AMC), focusing on goals like pain management, endurance in walking, and daily activities.
results_summary: The study found that remote delivery of the home exercise program was feasible, with participants achieving 12 of 15 individualized goals and showing statistically significant improvements in pain and comfort as well as physical activity levels.
population_specificity: Youths aged 8-21 years with arthrogryposis multiplex congenita (AMC).
effective_dosage: Participants performed their home exercise program 2.04 times per week on average.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a quad-cane with an auxiliary laser illuminator (laser-cane) on gait parameters, balance, and daily living activities in stroke patients.
results_summary: Both groups improved in cadence, balance, and mobility, but the experimental group showed additional improvements in stride length, gait speed, and gait symmetry. The laser-cane group demonstrated better outcomes in gait symmetry and specific gait parameters compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Stroke patients
effective_dosage: 15 minutes of walking training with laser-cane and 15 minutes of traditional physical therapy, twice per week

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a non-immersive VR exercise program during dialysis could improve physical function and exercise adherence in chronic kidney disease patients.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in physical function, including gait speed, balance, and endurance, with adherence rates exceeding 70%. No changes were observed in biochemical data or medications during the study.
population_specificity: 56 individuals with chronic kidney disease undergoing dialysis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (VR exercise program administered during dialysis sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of fetoscopic repair of spina bifida on preventing walking disability and improving postnatal psychomotor development.
results_summary: The study found that prenatal fetoscopic closure of myelomeningocele was associated with improved postnatal psychomotor development and reduced risk of walking disability and Arnold-Chiari II malformation, despite risks of premature labor and placental abruption.
population_specificity: A fetus diagnosed with lumbosacral myelomeningocele at 23 weeks gestation.
study_duration: Intervention performed at 26 weeks gestation, with follow-up until emergency C-section at 32 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-flow nasal cannula therapy improves arterial blood gas levels and 6-minute walking distance in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) patients.
results_summary: High-flow nasal cannula did not significantly decrease partial pressure of carbon dioxide or increase partial pressure of oxygen in COPD patients but improved transcutaneous partial pressure of carbon dioxide and increased 6-minute walking distance.
population_specificity: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical effectiveness and safety of an expanded scope allied health model of care (TAP) for chronic pain patients, including its impact on walking endurance.
results_summary: The TAP group showed statistically significant improvements in walking endurance (5.4 m increase) and reduced pain interference compared to the waitlist group, with no adverse events reported.
population_specificity: Tertiary-referral chronic pain patients (n=181).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of veverimer on metabolic acidosis and physical function (including walking) in patients with diabetes and chronic kidney disease.
results_summary: Veverimer significantly improved serum bicarbonate levels and patient-reported physical function (e.g., walking several blocks) compared to placebo. Objective physical performance, measured by the repeated chair stand test, also showed significant improvement.
population_specificity: Patients with diabetes and chronic kidney disease (estimated glomerular filtration rate 20-40 mL/min/1.73 m²) and metabolic acidosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of targeted nursing interventions, including mobilization (e.g., walking), on reducing functional and hospital-associated decline in older patients.
results_summary: Eight studies reported a significant increase in mobilization (e.g., sitting in a chair or walking), and four reported improved functional outcomes. The evidence suggests that nursing teams using evidence-translation frameworks can improve mobilization in acute care settings.
population_specificity: Older patients in acute care settings (medical, surgical, and older adult wards).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether contralateral S1 nerve root transfer improves motor function recovery in paralyzed limbs of patients with chronic CNSI compared to traditional treatments.
results_summary: The study is a prospective randomized controlled trial designed to evaluate the effectiveness of contralateral S1 nerve transfer, with primary outcomes measured by the Fugl-Meyer score for lower limbs and secondary outcomes including gait analysis, muscle strength, and functional MRI. Results are pending as the trial is ongoing.
population_specificity: Forty patients with hemiplegia caused by chronic central nervous system injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how obesity-related disability affects children's physical activity, including walking, and identify strategies to enhance movement.
results_summary: The study highlights that obesity in children leads to musculoskeletal pain and reduced physical function, impairing activities like walking and climbing stairs, and suggests addressing movement barriers to improve physical activity efficacy.
population_specificity: Children with obesity

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of onasemnogene abeparvovec versus nusinersen for treating spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) type 1, focusing on motor milestone achievements, including independent walking.
results_summary: The study found that onasemnogene abeparvovec showed a numerically greater likelihood of achieving independent walking by 18 and 24 months compared to nusinersen, though statistical significance was not consistently observed. Overall, onasemnogene abeparvovec demonstrated favorable outcomes in event-free survival, overall survival, and motor milestones.
population_specificity: Symptomatic patients with SMA type 1.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the 24-month efficacy and safety of drug-eluting stents (Eluvia and Zilver PTX) for treating peripheral artery disease in Japanese patients, focusing on clinical outcomes and walking impairment.
results_summary: The study found that Eluvia had lower clinically driven target lesion revascularization rates (5.6% vs. 18.5%) and higher freedom from TLR (94.3% vs. 80.4%) compared to Zilver PTX. Walking impairment scores improved and were sustained over time, with significant clinical improvements in Rutherford classification.
population_specificity: Japanese patients with femoropopliteal lesions (84 patients: 56 Eluvia, 28 Zilver PTX).

study_goal: To determine the short-term and long-term effects of robotic-assisted gait training (RAGT) on walking distance, gait speed, and functionality in cerebral palsy (CP) patients.
results_summary: RAGT significantly improved walking distance and showed large clinical effects in gait speed and functionality, with improvements maintained long-term. Gait speed results were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Children with cerebral palsy (CP)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of cybernic treatment using the Hybrid Assistive Limb (HAL) to improve ambulatory function in patients with incurable neuromuscular diseases.
results_summary: Cybernic treatment with HAL significantly improved walking distance in the two-minute walk test (2MWT) by 10.066% compared to conventional hoist-only treatment. Secondary endpoints showed significant improvements in manual muscle testing (MMT) scores and cadence, with only minor adverse effects like mild myalgia and skin contact issues.
population_specificity: Patients over 18 years old with neuromuscular diseases (e.g., spinal muscular atrophy, muscular dystrophy) who could not walk 10 meters independently.
effective_dosage: A 40-minute walking program performed nine times.
study_duration: The trial was conducted between March 6, 2013, and August 8, 2014.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of enhanced external counterpulsation (EECP) on exercise capacity and quality of life in patients with chronic heart failure (CHF).
results_summary: EECP significantly improved 6-minute walking distance and left ventricular ejection fraction but did not significantly reduce Minnesota Living with Heart Failure Questionnaire scores, indicating insufficient evidence for quality-of-life improvement.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic heart failure (CHF), especially the elderly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of standardized outpatient cardiac rehabilitation combined with treadmill power walking versus rehabilitation alone on health-related quality of life, functional exercise capacity, left ventricular ejection fraction, and metabolic equivalent of tasks in post-coronary angioplasty patients.
results_summary: The study found that combining cardiac rehabilitation with power walking significantly improved 6-minute walk test scores, left ventricular ejection fraction, health-related quality of life, metabolic equivalent of tasks, and average step counts compared to rehabilitation alone. Both interventions showed significant improvements after 4 weeks, but the combined approach was more effective.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent coronary angioplasty and participated in a cardiac rehabilitation program.
effective_dosage: Not specified (treadmill power walking as part of 12 treatment sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the cost-effectiveness and effectiveness of high-intensity walking training (HIT) versus conventional physical therapy in improving walking ability and quality of life in individuals with subacute stroke.
results_summary: HIT resulted in higher personnel costs but showed better outcomes in quality-adjusted life years (QALYs) and self-selected walking speeds (SSS) compared to conventional therapy. The incremental cost-effectiveness ratios suggested HIT was relatively inexpensive for the additional benefits gained.
population_specificity: Individuals with locomotor impairments 1-6 months poststroke (N=44).
effective_dosage: HIT targeted up to 80% maximum heart rate reserve; conventional therapy targeted <40% heart rate reserve.

study_goal: To assess the safety and efficacy of robot-assisted gait training (RAGT) with exoskeletons for children with Cerebral Palsy (CP) or Spinal Muscular Atrophy (SMA).
results_summary: RAGT therapy appears safe for children with CP, but efficacy results require further investigation. No evidence was found for RAGT therapy in SMA children.
population_specificity: Children aged 3-14 with CP or SMA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and outcomes of treating Danis-Weber type-B ankle fractures using a Pre-contoured Distal Fibular Locking Plate.
results_summary: The study found that 90% of patients had no difficulties walking on any surface, 96.67% had stable ankle hindfoot, and 86.67% had good alignment. The mean AOFAS score was 88.67±2.31, with 86.67% of patients achieving satisfactory outcomes.
population_specificity: 30 patients (22 male, 8 female) with an average age of 39 years and Danis-Weber type-B ankle fractures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the user acceptability of an instrumented shoe insole for monitoring walking speed and differentiating active walking from shuffling in frail older adults.
results_summary: The study found mixed acceptability results, with high usability scores but low reliability scores. Participant satisfaction with comfort improved over time, though technical issues led some to discontinue use. No significant differences in frailty parameters or quality of life were observed between the intervention and control groups.
population_specificity: Frail older adults (mean age 79 years).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (device use, not a supplement).
study_duration: Up to 3 months for the randomized trial.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of diet, exercise, and combined interventions on muscle mass and functional outcomes in obese individuals with lower-limb osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found that combined diet and resistance exercise, resistance exercise alone, and aerobic exercise alone were most effective for increasing muscle mass, strength, and walking speed. Walking speed improved with aerobic exercise (SMD = 0.46).
population_specificity: Overweight or obese adults with lower-limb osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of balloon pulmonary angioplasty (BPA) for chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH) using a multicentre registry.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in haemodynamic, functional, and biochemical parameters after BPA, including increased six-minute walking test (6MWT) distance from 341±129 to 423±136 m (p<0.001). Complication rates were low, and overall survival was 92.4% three years after the initial BPA procedure.
population_specificity: 236 patients with confirmed CTEPH (124 women; mean age 67 years) in Poland.
study_duration: Median follow-up of 5.9 (IQR: 3.0-8.0) months after final BPA

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate assays for quantifying circulating cell-free DNA (cfDNA) in blood plasma without DNA isolation and study the kinetics of cfDNA after walking exercise in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
results_summary: The study found that cfDNA levels in SLE patients increased approximately twofold after walking exercise and normalized after 60 minutes of rest. The validated assays demonstrated reliable and cost-efficient cfDNA quantification with high precision and low limits of detection.
population_specificity: Patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
study_duration: Not specified (exercise and 60-minute rest period observed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the benefits of walking and other aerobic exercises in reducing disabilities associated with diabetic neuropathy.
results_summary: Walking and other aerobic exercises were found to be effective in improving vascular and neuronal health, aiding in both treatment and prevention of diabetic neuropathy. The study highlighted their positive effects, including anti-oxidant, anti-inflammatory, and neuroprotective actions.
population_specificity: Patients with diabetic neuropathy (approximately 50% of diabetes mellitus patients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of foot-ankle flexibility and resistance exercises on diabetic ulcer recurrence, neuropathy, and walking speed in patients with recently healed plantar foot diabetic ulcers.
results_summary: The study found that foot-ankle exercises significantly reduced ulcer recurrence rates (16% vs. 72% in controls at 24 weeks) and improved diabetic neuropathy scores and walking speed, but did not significantly affect HbA1c levels or ankle brachial index.
population_specificity: Fifty patients with recently healed plantar foot diabetic ulcers.
effective_dosage: Foot-ankle flexibility and resistance exercises three times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of 7-month intradialytic exercise training (including walking) on muscle architecture, functional capacity, and quality of life in stable haemodialysis patients.
results_summary: The exercise group showed preserved muscle thickness and significant improvements in functional capacity (e.g., 6-minute walking test, maximal aerobic power) compared to the control group, though muscle architecture (fascicle angle and length) did not change significantly.
population_specificity: Stable haemodialysis patients
effective_dosage: 60% of pre-assessed maximum aerobic power, 3 times per week

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of cilostazol on walking distance (initial and absolute claudication distances), mortality, and vascular events in patients with stable intermittent claudication due to peripheral arterial disease (PAD).
results_summary: Cilostazol improved walking distance (both initial and absolute claudication distances) compared to placebo, but participants experienced increased odds of headaches. No significant difference was found between cilostazol and pentoxifylline for improving walking distance, and data on serious outcomes like amputation or cardiovascular events were insufficient.
population_specificity: Patients with intermittent claudication secondary to PAD, aged predominantly over 55.
effective_dosage: Cilostazol dose ranged from 100 mg to 300 mg; pentoxifylline dose ranged from 800 mg to 1200 mg.
study_duration: Treatment duration ranged from 6 to 26 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the use of the Margin of Stability (MoS) in evaluating dynamic stability during gait in pathological populations and to examine the methods and interpretations of MoS data.
results_summary: The study found that the MoS is used to assess stability in over 15 different clinical populations, most commonly post-stroke and unilateral transtibial amputees. However, methodological and interpretational variability hinders direct comparisons between studies, and a lack of large baseline studies limits strong conclusions.
population_specificity: Adult human populations with pathological gait, including post-stroke and unilateral transtibial amputees.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a 6-week, low-to-moderate intensity walking intervention on health-related outcomes (body composition, hemodynamic changes, and functionality) in older adults with multimorbidity.
results_summary: The intervention significantly reduced blood pressure and waist circumference while improving muscle mass and functionality, particularly walking speed and balance skills. The exercise group showed a 73% likelihood of greater muscle mass improvement compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 24 individuals aged 65 and older with multimorbidity.
effective_dosage: 60 minutes per week of low-to-moderate intensity walking (perceived effort 3-6 on an 11-point scale).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an interdisciplinary evaluation involving a physical therapist and surgeon influenced treatment plans and decisional conflict in patients with nonarthritic hip pain, including movement assessments during walking.
results_summary: The interdisciplinary evaluation increased interest in physical therapy (66% vs. 48%) but was not statistically significant. Both groups showed similar reductions in decisional conflict, though the interdisciplinary group reported slightly lower post-evaluation conflict.
population_specificity: Adults with primary nonarthritic hip pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether lower gait speed in frail or prefrail older adults with type 2 diabetes is associated with faster cognitive decline.
results_summary: Slow walkers showed a steeper decline in category fluency scores compared to fast walkers, with a moderate effect size. No significant differences were found in MMSE scores or other cognitive measures between the groups.
population_specificity: Frail or prefrail older adults (>70 years) with type 2 diabetes and no history of cognitive problems.

study_goal: The researchers reviewed advancements in gene editing and modulation therapies for treating Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD), focusing on those closest to clinical application.
results_summary: The abstract highlights progress in gene therapies for DMD, including gene replacement and splicing modulation, but notes uncertainties regarding durability and efficacy. Experimental therapies using somatic cell gene editing are advancing toward clinical trials, though safety and translatable efficacy questions remain.
population_specificity: Individuals with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if early postoperative walking was associated with improved outcomes (low disability, minimal pain, no opioid use) one year after lumbar spine surgery and to establish a steps/day threshold for clinical guidance.
results_summary: Walking ≥3500 steps/day at 6 weeks post-surgery was linked to significantly higher odds of achieving "best outcome" (3.75x) and avoiding opioid use (2.37x) at one year. Each additional 1000 steps/day increased the odds of these outcomes by 41% and 38%, respectively.
population_specificity: 212 participants (mean age 62.8±11.4y, 53.3% female) undergoing surgery for degenerative lumbar spine conditions.
study_duration: Walking assessed at 6 weeks post-surgery, outcomes measured at 1 year.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether home-based walking could improve pregnancy outcomes and mood in sedentary Japanese women.
results_summary: The walking group showed reduced depression-dejection and confusion scores but no differences in pregnancy or delivery outcomes. Only 9.2% completed the full walking program, while 59.3% completed at least 80%.
population_specificity: Sedentary Japanese women aged 22-36 years during pregnancy.
effective_dosage: Brisk walking for 30 minutes, three times weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and validate a new gait classification system for adult patients with chronic hemiparesis based on key walking abnormalities.
results_summary: The proposed classification successfully differentiated patients into groups and subgroups based on significant differences in walking speed and kinematic parameters, with nearly two-thirds of the 25 parameters showing significant differences (p<0.05). However, further validation with a larger sample size and assessment of inter-operator repeatability is needed.
population_specificity: Adult patients with hemiparesis in the chronic phase resulting from a central nervous system lesion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the direct effects of a single session of walking on biochemical markers of bone metabolism in participants with low bone mass.
results_summary: Walking increased sclerostin levels significantly compared to the control group but did not significantly affect bone-specific alkaline phosphatase (BALP) or carboxy-terminal cross-linked telopeptide of type I collagen (CTX) concentrations. Resistance exercise showed a significant effect on CTX, unlike walking.
population_specificity: 50 otherwise healthy female subjects (mean age 59.1 ± 7.1 years) diagnosed with osteoporosis or osteopenia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the use of powered robotic exoskeletons for gait rehabilitation in adults post-stroke and map the current literature on their effectiveness.
results_summary: The review found that exoskeleton-based gait training showed meaningful improvement in sub-acute stroke patients but was equivalent to traditional therapy in chronic stroke patients. Two of four controlled trials showed no greater improvement in walking outcomes for chronic stroke patients compared to controls.
population_specificity: Adult stroke survivors, ranging from sub-acute (<7 weeks) to chronic (>6 months) post-stroke.
study_duration: Training periods ranged from single-session to 8-week interventions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether estimated energy expenditure or posture allocation from activity monitors (including walking) predicted weight change during and after a low-calorie diet, and to compare device accuracy against doubly labeled water.
results_summary: More time spent walking at baseline, measured by the IDEEA, significantly predicted greater weight loss during the 8-week low-calorie diet. Measures of posture allocation showed medium effect sizes in their relationships with weight change.
population_specificity: 87 participants from 2 clinical trials.
study_duration: 8-week low-calorie diet, with follow-ups at 6 and 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of functional electrical stimulation on muscle sympathetic nerve activity, muscle blood flow, and exercise tolerance in hospitalized heart failure patients.
results_summary: Functional electrical stimulation significantly reduced muscle sympathetic nerve activity, increased muscle blood flow and strength, and improved walking distance and quality of life more than the control group. Both groups showed improvements in walking distance and quality of life, but the effects were greater in the functional electrical stimulation group.
population_specificity: Hospitalized patients with decompensated heart failure (NYHA class IV, ejection fraction ≤30%).
effective_dosage: 10 Hz frequency, 150 ms pulse width, 70 mA intensity for 60 minutes/day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and performance of the ESPRIT BVS system, a drug-eluting bioresorbable vascular scaffold, for treating peripheral artery disease (PAD) in the external iliac artery and superficial femoral artery.
results_summary: The study found successful deployment of the scaffold in all cases, with minor complications in 3 patients. At 2 years, 71.0% of patients were Rutherford-Becker 0, and 93.5% achieved a maximum walking distance of 1,500 feet, indicating improved outcomes.
population_specificity: 35 subjects with symptomatic claudication due to PAD involving the external iliac artery and superficial femoral artery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the predictive power of in-hospital walking activity versus activities of daily living (ADLs) for 30-day readmission risk in older acutely ill patients and identify preliminary walking thresholds to reduce rehospitalizations.
results_summary: Walking activity during hospitalization was more strongly associated with reduced 30-day readmission risk than ADL function, with a threshold of 275+ steps/day identifying lower-risk patients. Predictive accuracy was highest for models including walking activity.
population_specificity: 164 ambulatory adults aged 65+ admitted to an acute care hospital for acute medical illness.
effective_dosage: Not specified (step counts measured via accelerometry).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the relationship between tactile discrimination of the hand, avoidance behaviors towards social touch, and frailty criteria, including slow walking speed, in institutionalized elders.
results_summary: The study found that slow walking speed was one of the phenotype frailty criteria examined, but the abstract does not report specific findings about walking's effects beyond its inclusion as a frailty marker.
population_specificity: Institutionalized elders aged 68-99 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of superficial cooling and warming of the lower leg on walking speed and neuromuscular impairments in people with hereditary and spontaneous spastic paraparesis (HSSP) and healthy controls.
results_summary: Cooling decreased walking speed, especially for HSSP participants, and worsened neuromuscular impairments like dorsiflexor force generation and spasticity. Warming improved dorsiflexor force generation and nerve conduction velocity while reducing spasticity.
population_specificity: 22 HSSP participants and 19 matched healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether treadmill-integrated ankle robotics training is more effective than seated ankle robotics training for improving gait function in chronic stroke patients.
results_summary: Treadmill-integrated ankle robotics training significantly improved walking velocity, paretic single support, push-off impulse, and dorsiflexion range of motion compared to seated training, with durable benefits in gait biomechanics and reduced reliance on assistive devices.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke patients with hemiparetic gait.
effective_dosage: Six weeks of training (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a single injection of platelet-rich plasma (PRP) would improve outcomes more effectively than placebo (saline) in patients with chronic Achilles tendinopathy (AT) after 3 months.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference between PRP and saline injections in improving VISA-A scores or most secondary outcomes (pain at rest, pain while walking, pain when tendon was squeezed, and color Doppler activity) after 3 months. The only statistically significant difference was an increase in tendon thickness in the PRP group compared to the saline group.
population_specificity: 24 patients with chronic Achilles tendinopathy (median disease duration, 33 months).
effective_dosage: Single injection of PRP or saline.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of interventions, including walking groups, to increase physical activity and improve dietary behaviors among Vietnamese adults aged 50-65 with metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: The study implemented a 6-month community-based intervention involving walking groups, education, and resistance bands, but the abstract does not provide specific outcome data on walking's effects.
population_specificity: Vietnamese adults aged 50-65 with metabolic syndrome.
effective_dosage: Not specified (attendance at local walking groups encouraged).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the ACE inhibitor enalapril could enhance improvements in exercise capacity during pulmonary rehabilitation in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
results_summary: The study found that enalapril, combined with pulmonary rehabilitation, reduced the peak work rate response to exercise training in COPD patients without an established indication for ACE inhibition.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) who had at least moderate airflow obstruction and were participating in pulmonary rehabilitation (age 67 ± 8 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a physical activity intervention (PAI) involving walking improved psychological and motivational processes related to physical activity adoption compared to standard presurgical care (SC) in bariatric surgery patients.
results_summary: The PAI group showed greater improvements in PA-related enjoyment, self-efficacy, and motivations compared to the SC group, though changes in objectively measured PA were not associated with psychological/motivational improvements.
population_specificity: Bariatric surgery patients (87% female, average BMI 45.0±6.5 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: Weekly counseling sessions to increase daily walking exercise (specific duration/frequency not detailed).
